content.question: The size of a population is modeled by the function <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of P, with respect to t, equals, one tenth times P, minus the fraction 1 over 5000, end fraction, times P squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>P</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5000</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in months and <math alttext="P of 0, equals 50 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the size of the population at the moment when the population is growing most rapidly?

topic.text: 7.9: (BC ONLY) Logistic Models with Differential Equations

skill.text: Skill 3.F: Explain the meaning of mathematical solutions in context.
